title: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Safety and Tolerability of Multiple Dose Regimens of CHF 5074 and to Explore the Effects in Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment
description_brief: To evaluate the safety and tolerability of ascending oral doses of CHF 5074 administered once per day for up to 12 weeks to patients with mild cognitive impairment.

groups.title: CHF 5074 1x
groups.description:
oral tablet, multidose

CHF 5074 1x: oral tablet, 1x, once a day in the morning for 12 weeks

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

explanation_target: Reason: The investigational agent CHF 5074 is described in the literature as a small-molecule gamma-secretase modulator and a flurbiprofen-analogue that lowers Aβ (amyloid-β) production and has anti‑inflammatory/microglial‑modulating effects — i.e., it targets Alzheimer’s pathology rather than being a biologic, a symptomatic cognitive enhancer only, or a neuropsychiatric‑symptom drug. citeturn0search6turn0search2

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description — ascending oral doses of CHF 5074 once daily for up to 12 weeks in patients with mild cognitive impairment (randomized, placebo‑controlled). The 12‑week, ascending‑dose safety/tolerability study and pharmacodynamic measurements in MCI patients are reported in the literature. These characterize CHF5074 as a small‑molecule, disease‑targeting agent (gamma‑secretase modulator) tested for effects on amyloid/tau and neuroinflammation. citeturn0search1turn0search7

Reflect: Classification check — CHF5074 is not a biologic (no monoclonal antibody or vaccine), and its main described action is modulation of γ‑secretase / reduction of Aβ and modulation of microglial inflammation, consistent with a disease‑targeted small molecule. Therefore the best fit among the provided categories is 'disease‑targeted small molecule'. I found multiple preclinical and clinical references supporting this mechanism and the 12‑week MCI study. citeturn0search4turn0search0

Web search results (selected sources supporting the above): 1) 12‑week double‑blind, placebo‑controlled ascending‑dose MCI study reporting safety/tolerability and biomarker measures (CHF5074). citeturn0search1 2) Preclinical and mechanistic reports describing CHF5074 as a γ‑secretase modulator that reduces Aβ and improves cognition in AD mouse models. citeturn0search6turn0search3 3) Comparative profiling showing CHF5074 is a flurbiprofen analogue with Abeta42‑lowering activity. citeturn0search2 4) BMC Neuroscience review/long‑term in vivo study describing multimodal actions (amyloid lowering, reduced microglial activation) and tolerability. citeturn0search4 5) Trial registry/summary entry for the NCT01303744 study (Evaluation of Safety & Tolerability of Multiple Dose Regimens of CHF 5074 in MCI). citeturn0search7
explanation_agent: Reason: CHF‑5074 (itanapraced, CSP‑1103) is a small‑molecule γ‑secretase modulator that lowers Aβ (Aβ42/Aβ40) and is described also as a microglial / anti‑inflammatory modulator. Both amyloid‑lowering and neuroinflammation/microglial modulation are described mechanisms for this agent, so the trial implicates more than one CADRO biological target. citeturn0search3turn0search5turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — investigational drug CHF‑5074 (CSP‑1103, itanapraced), oral small molecule; tested in a 12‑week, randomized, placebo‑controlled, ascending‑dose study in MCI with pharmacodynamic biomarker readouts showing dose‑dependent reductions in CNS inflammatory biomarkers (CSF sCD40L, TNF‑α) and the compound is reported to reduce Aβ species in preclinical and biochemical assays. These facts support classifying the trial as targeting both amyloid biology and neuroinflammation. citeturn0search1turn0search2turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — because CHF‑5074 has documented Aβ‑lowering activity (γ‑secretase modulation) and independently reported microglial/anti‑inflammatory effects, the most specific CADRO assignment is R) Multi‑target rather than choosing only A) Amyloid beta or only F) Inflammation. If one needed a single‑mechanism label and the study focused solely on Aβ outcomes, A) Amyloid beta could be argued, but the dual actions reported in the literature warrant Multi‑target. citeturn0search3turn0search2turn0search1

Web search results used (selected): 1) 12‑week double‑blind, placebo‑controlled MCI study reporting safety/tolerability and reductions in CSF/plasma inflammatory biomarkers (sCD40L, TNF‑α). citeturn0search1 2) Preclinical study showing CHF‑5074 induces an anti‑inflammatory / M2‑like microglial response in Tg2576 mice and in vitro, supporting a microglial‑modulating mechanism. citeturn0search2 3) Product/mechanism summaries and catalogs describing CHF‑5074 (itanapraced, CSP‑1103) as an orally active γ‑secretase modulator that lowers Aβ42/Aβ40. citeturn0search3turn0search5 4) Additional chemical/product summary supporting γ‑secretase modulation and Aβ lowering in preclinical studies. citeturn0search4
